The Future of the
Catskills Interpretive Center

    Reimagining the Catskill Interpretive Center

    It’s critically important to have a place where residents and visitors can learn about our unique natural, historical, and cultural resources. It will help preserve our rich heritage, keep our local economies strong, and our quality of life intact.

    Hon. Rep. Maurice D. Hinchey

    U.S. Representative, 1993 – 2013

    The Maurice D. Hinchey Catskill Interpretive Center is a partnership between the Catskill Center and the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation.

    More than just a visitors center for the Catskill Park, the reimagined Catskill Interpretive Center will act as a community Gathering Space, a Mountain House, Ranger Station, Observatory and Research Lab.

    Situated on 60 acres of forest, fields and wetlands in the hamlet of Mount Tremper, the center is already known to the community for its walking trails, sculpture park showcasing local Catskill artisans, picnic areas, and access to the Esopus Creek.

  • PreviousNext

    The redesign of the interpretive elements of the Center will further the interpretive mission of CCCD; function as a central hub for local community engagement; orient visitors to tourist sites, current attractions, outdoor activities, and seasonal offerings in the park’s communities; and educate visitors and locals alike about the area’s rich natural and cultural history while promoting the importance of stewardship, conservation, and protection of the Catskills Park.

    Get Involved

    of Nature

    A Future for the Catskill Interpretive Center

    Past Catskills visitors included illustrious painters, authors, naturalists, and explorers, as well as everyday people seeking a break from the city. Visitors of all walks of life came to the Catskills, bringing an appreciation for nature and a desire for fresh air, relaxation, and recreation among the region’s natural wonders and unspoiled natural sights.

    Visitors to the Catskill Interpretive Center will come away with an overview of the area’s rich natural and cultural history, discover local attractions and activities, and gain a broader sense of the importance of stewardship, conservation, and protection of the Catskills Park.

    The Catskills Interpretive Center will provide content in the following areas:
    • Tourist Information

      The Center will provide a concierge experience that brings together practical content to assist visitors in making the most of their visit to the Catskills. This information includes local hotels and restaurants, as well as outdoor activities and cultural attractions. Augmenting this information are resources produced by the CIC. Bringing together all this content in one place will allow the CIC to serve as a hub for regional tourism – an important source of economic activity and local employment.

  • PreviousNext
    • Outdoor Activities

      The Center will bring together and reinterpret the various ways that tourists and locals can engage with the natural Catskills environment. In addition to hiking trails, this sections covers a wide range of outdoor activities. Content in “Outdoor Activities” brings the trailhead into the CIC and gives visitors context and options for their outdoor adventures.

    Caption #1

    Cras justo odio, dapibus ac facilisis in, egestas eget quam. Donec id elit non mi porta gravida at eget metus. Nullam id dolor id nibh ultricies vehicula ut id elit.

  • PreviousNext
    • Natural Environment

      The Center will present detailed information and resources on the ecological systems, wildlife and geology in the Catskills. This includes things like: Phenology, Animals, Native mammals and reptiles, Native birds and visiting birds, Endangered and threatened species, Plants, Ecological Zones, Geology, Watershed, Ecosystem Services, Climate Change.

  • PreviousNext
    • Catskills Past and Present

      The Center will invite visitors to learn about the history of the Catskill region, from the indigenous Lenapehoking to the Hudson River School, to how the region is changing currently. Content will situate the present day Catskills within a centuries-long history of development, “enjoyment of natural resources,” and conservation.

  • PreviousNext

    Visitors to the Catskill Interpretive Center will come away with an overview of the area’s rich natural and cultural history, discover local attractions and activities, and gain a broader sense of the importance of stewardship, conservation, and protection of the Catskills Park.

    We are reinventing the Maurice D. Hinchey Catskills Interpretive Center. Our plan for the Center includes the design of new interactive exhibits for the Center about the park, its plants, wildlife, waterways, history, culture, and people; creating a first-of-its-kind app for visitors and locals alike to learn about events in the region; repositioning the center as a ranger station and mountain house.

    Activating the Archive

    Since 1969, the Catskill Center has been protecting and fostering the environmental, cultural and economic well-being of the Catskill region. Along the way, the Center has developed an extensive archive of Park-related research materials, phenological data, oral histories, environmental curriculum, charismatic objects, art, crafts, along with books by local naturalists, botanists, geologists and conservationists.

    The new Interpretive Center will engage with the Center’s archive, allowing the public to experience the history of the region.

    Bringing the past to the present

    From pre-European settlement to the emergence of the Catskills as a tourist destination through the work of Hudson River School painters, the Center will also exhibit how the region is changing currently with a growth in tourism, the role of Catskills reservoirs in New York City’s water system, and threats to the region’s ecosystem through invasive species and climate change.

    The New Visitor Experience

    Celebrating nature and the history of tourism — Drawing on the history of tourism and hospitality in the region, the Center will provide visitors with a concierge experience that brings together practical content to assist them in making the most of their visit to the Catskills. This information includes local hotels and restaurants, as well as outdoor activities and cultural attractions. Augmenting this information are resources produced by the CIC. Bringing together all this content in one place will allow the CIC to serve as a hub for regional tourism – an important source of economic activity and local employment.

    Gathering and discovering

    The newly designed Catskills Interpretive Center will be a gathering place for locals and tourists alike. The Center will provide space for public events, workshops, classes, and regular naturalist-guided walks and tours will depart from the Center’s indoor trailhead.
